options: Remove him from the practice list if he refuses to give up smoking
Alter his inhaler treatment and raise it at the practice meeting
Alter his inhaler treatment and speak to the doctor concerned
Refuse to alter his inhaler treatment until he has agreed to be referred to smoking cessation
Alter his inhaler treatment and advise the patient to see you next time
questions:
You are a F2 doctor in General Practice. You see a 29-year-old man with asthma. He tells you he has come to see you today because one of the partners refuses to alter his inhaler therapy until he gives up smoking. He is currently using a salbutamol inhaler as required but is now having frequent episodes of wheeze and he has developed a nocturnal cough.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Although continuing to smoke is clearly going to make his asthma control worse it is not a reason to withhold treatment from a patient. After being made aware of this you have duty to follow it up with the doctor concerned. This also allows the doctor to explain the consultation from his/her point of view. Raising this at the practice meeting is less ideal as it may appear confrontational.

Altering his inhaler treatment alone fails to address the issue of treatment being withheld. Refusing to alter his inhalers until he has agreed to be referred to smoking cessation is basically blackmail and not acceptable. Removing him from the practice list for not giving up smoking again is clearly wrong.
question:

Removing him from the practice list for not giving up smoking again is clearly wrong.

Confidentiality guidance

options: Remove the information from the computer notes, print it out and place in the paper notes to avoid accidental browsing
Explain that you are not allowed to remove such material from the medical notes
Remove from the record any mention of the contraceptive pill to maintain confidentiality and respect autonomy
Explore why she is now concerned her mother will find out
Sack her mother
Ask her mother to sign a confidentiality clause
Suggest she moves to a different practice
Reassure her that the receptionists are not allowed to browse through the medical records
questions:
You are a F2 doctor in General Practice. During a consultation with a 25-year-old woman she asks you to remove from the records any mention of her being on the contraceptive pill when she was 14-years-old. She is concerned as her mother works as a receptionist at the practice and may see her records.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
Difficult one. Medical notes can only be amended if the previous entry was false. This is not the case here so the record of her contraceptive pill use should not be removed. Such information may of course be relevant clinically in the future as well. Exploring why she is concerned may reveal underlying issues and allow you to allay her fears.

If the information is removed from the computer notes and printed out then it will not available during future consultations. Staff are already bound by confidentiality so asking her mother to sign a confidentiality clause is unnecessary.
question:
You are a F2 doctor in General Practice. During a consultation with a 25-year-old woman she asks you to remove from the records any mention of her being on the contraceptive pill when she was 14-years-old. options: Send an anonymous e-mail to the Infection Control department
Fill in a clinical incident form
Speak to the Ward Manager and ask her/him to speak to the doctor
Remind him of the hospital infection control policy
Speak to his consultant about the issue
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor in medicine. One of your ST1 colleagues who is based on the same ward regularly wears long-sleeve shirts and a watch in contravention of the hospital infection control policy.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
A degree of judgement is required here. Whilst infection control is an important and integral part of safe patient care it is important not to alienate other members of staff unnecessarily.

The best response is D, to simply remind him of the hospital infection control policy. The next best response is C. Ward managers have a considerable degree of authority and autonomy and hence would be in a good place to remind the doctor of the need to follow hospital policies. The Ward manager would be in a better place than his consultant (option E) to monitor and enforce this.

Clinical incident forms and not really designed for such episodes unless the doctor refuses to change his ways once it has been pointed out.

Sending an anonymous e-mail to infection control is unprofessional and unnecessary.
question:

options: Continue working but only do drug charts and discharge summaries to avoid patient contact.
Continue working as usual as food poisoning is not contagious.
Take sick leave for one day and return to work if you have stopped vomiting the next day.
Take sick leave for as long as is advised by hospital policies.
Take annual leave until you feel completely back to normal.
Inform your consultant.
Inform your Educational Supervisor.
Inform medical staffing.
questions:
You are a FY2 working in Paediatrics. You think you might have eaten something dodgy last night as you have developed diarrhoea and vomiting.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
The correct options here are 4 (sick leave according to policy), 6 (inform consultant), and 8 (inform medical staffing).

  • You should follow hospital policies on sick leave when unwell (option 4). Many hospitals have specific policies on diarrhoea and vomiting, which usually involve sick leave while symptomatic, with an additional 'paid special leave' enforced for 48 hours after the last symptoms have settled. This will vary between trusts.
  • When you are unable to come into work for whatever reason, whenever possible, you should inform your team of this fact (option 6). Ideally you should ring the ward and tell one of your colleagues directly or ask the ward clerk to pass on a message.
  • You should also inform medical staffing (option 8) in case they need to arrange locums/extra cover and to sort out your sick leave.
  • Illness is not an appropriate use for annual leave (option 5)
  • It may be tempting to not take leave when you become unwell, especially if the symptoms are manageable. However you must be aware that by doing so you are putting vulnerable patients at risk of disease transmission (option 1 and 2)

GMC 'Good Medical Practice':
- If you know or suspect that you have a serious condition that you could pass on to patients, or if your judgement or performance could be affected by a condition or its treatment, you must consult a suitably qualified colleague. You must follow their advice about any changes to your practice they consider necessary. You must not rely on your own assessment of the risk to patients.

This is more important with serious conditions such as HIV or Hepatitis B, but the same principles apply here, as immunocompromised patients can become dangerously unwell even with a simple viral illness.

options: Prescribe yourself a course of fluoxetine
Take sick leave until you feel better
Speak to your Consultant
Speak to the Postgraduate Dean
Go and see your GP
questions:
You are a ST1 in General Medicine. Your job is currently very busy due to a shortage of junior doctors. You notice that you are sleeping poorly and have a poor appetite. You have also stopped enjoying things you used to look forward.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This scenario describes a doctor with some features of depression. One of the key principles of the GMC document 'Good Medical Practice' is ensuring you are in a fit state to provide medical care. It states the following:
'You should be registered with a general practitioner outside your family to ensure that you have access to independent and objective medical care. You should not treat yourself.'

The best option is therefore to go and see your GP. Speaking to your consultant is an option but this presumes the depressive symptoms are entirely due to the current workload. He or she may, however, be able to make changes to alleviate the situation. The postgraduate dean has little control in the short-term over your workload, but may make longer-term changes if training is affected.

Taking sick leave is a poor option as this should only be done with the guidance of a doctor in the context of depression. It also is unlikely to address the underlying causes.

Treating yourself is the worst option. Please see the GMC guidance above.

GMC94
Confidentiality guidance

options: Contact the Driving and Vehicle Licencing Agency (DVLA) whilst the patient is in the room, in order to make sure he doesn't drive out of the practice
Explore the issue with the patient and find out why he had driven in
Explain the importance of the matter to the patient and why it is important that he does not drive until he has been seen in the clinic
Tell him that it is unacceptable that he is putting himself and others lives at risk
Contact the DVLA
Let the patient know that if he continues to drive that you have a legal obligation to inform the DVLA
Discuss your concerns with the patients partner over the phone
Speak to the family, and ask them to keep an eye out and report back to you if they see him driving
questions:
You see a 21-year-old in your GP practice who had a seizure last week. He is awaiting an appointment in the first fit clinic. You happened to notice him drive into the practise and on the emergency department note you see that he has been instructed not to drive.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
The GMCs guidelines on driving is a popular topic for questions.

In this situation, the patient should not be driving, however it will be important to establish that he understands this and agrees with this (option 2 and 3).

With regards to contacting the DVLA, at this point in time, option 6 would be the most appropriate. If he were to then continue to drive, you would be obliged to contact the DVLA, which is why 6 is better than 1 or 5. In the latest update, the GMC advice states that contacting the DVLA yourself 'should only be taken as a last resort, if efforts to encourage the patient to act responsibly fail.' Without first speaking to the patient, it cannot be the best option to contact the DVLA. It may be that the patient had not understood or recalled the advice given in the emergency department.

Option 4 demonstrates fairly poor communication skills and fails to engage with the patient. Option 7 or 8 would not be appropriate options routes of escalation.

title: GMC: Confidentiality: patients' fitness to drive and reporting concerns to the DVLA or DVA
body:
Trust is a central part of the doctor-patient relationship and is part of our daily practice. This can be put at risk by breaking confidentiality. Fitness to drive is one area where it is important to know what is expected of you, in both a legal and moral sense. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA)/ Vehicle Agency (DVA) are legally responsible for deciding if a person is medically unfit to drive. This means they need to know if a person holding a driving licence has a condition or is undergoing treatment that may affect their safety as a driver.

First off, it is the driver's legal responsibility to tell the DVLA or DVA about any condition or treatment. Doctors should alert patients to conditions and treatments that might affect their ability to drive and remind them of their duty to tell the appropriate agency. However, doctors may need to make a decision about whether to disclose relevant information without consent if a patient is unfit to drive but continues to do so.

You should always ask for a patient's consent before disclosing information for the protection of others (if it is safe, appropriate or practicable to do so). If it is not possible to seek consent or the patient has refused, disclosing personal information may be justified. This is particularly when there is a risk of death or serious harm to others. The benefits of disclosure must outweigh the interest in keeping the information confidential.

Problems with breaking confidentiality:
  • Patients may avoid seeking medical help, or may under-report symptoms.
  • Consultations may become more strained or mistrusting.
  • Complaints may be made against the doctor or practice.

You should not ask for consent if you have already decided to disclose information in the public interest but, if possible, you should tell the patient about your intention to disclose personal information. If the patient objects to the disclosure you should consider any reasons they give for objecting.

Reasons that the patient may object to sharing of information:
  • They are concerned about the implications for work, family or other areas.
  • In principle, they do not feel that it is your place to share the information.
  • They do not understand the reason for the information sharing.

When deciding whether the public interest outweighs potential harm, consider:
  • The potential harm or distress to the patient arising from the disclosure.
  • The potential harm to trust in doctors generally.
  • The potential harm to others if the information is not disclosed.
  • The potential benefits to an individual or society due to the release of the information.
  • The nature of the information to be disclosed, and any views expressed by the patient.
  • Whether the harms can be avoided or benefits gained without breaching the patient's privacy.

When diagnosing a patient's condition, or providing or arranging treatment, you should consider whether the condition or treatment may affect their ability to drive safely. To help determine this, you can refer to the DVLA's guidance on assessing fitness to drive. You may also seek the advice of an experienced colleague or the DVLA medical adviser.

If a patient has a condition or is undergoing treatment that could impair their fitness to drive, you should:
  • Explain this to the patient and tell them that they have a legal duty to inform the DVLA.
  • Tell the patient that you may be obliged to disclose relevant medical information about them, if they continue to drive when they are not fit to do so.
  • Make a note of any advice you have given to a patient in their medical record.
  • If a patient is incapable of understanding this advice, such as in cognitive impairment, you should inform the DVLA as soon as practicable.

The patient is welcome to seek a second medical opinion, and you should help facilitate this. However, you should still advise them not to drive in the meantime. If you become aware that a patient is continuing to drive when they may not be fit to do so, you should make every reasonable effort to persuade them to stop. Only then, would you consider breaching confidentiality. This is not an easy decision to make, but may be necessary for the safety of others.
links:
GMC00
GMC: Confidentiality: patients' fitness to drive and reporting concerns to the DVLA or DVA links

options: Inform the patient of what has happened
Reprimand the nurses who have given the prescription
Bleep the doctor who has prescribed the drugs to inform him/her of their error
Transfer her to the liver ward as a precaution
Fill out a yellow card
Complete a clinical incident form
Check paracetamol levels
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor in medicine. Whilst on-call you review a patient with persistent headaches. On inspection of her drug chart you notice she is prescribed both co-codamol and paracetamol on an 'as required' basis. In total she has had more than 4g of paracetamol on two consecutive days. You delete the prescriptions and inform the senior ward nurse.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
The first priority is to ensure the patient has come to no harm. Whilst the doses involved make this unlikely it is clearly appropriate to check her paracetamol levels, not least to reassure the patient who should have been informed about the error. From a clinical point of view this is technically a 'staggered overdose' so consideration should be given to whether acetylecysteine is appropriate, although this is probably not necessary given the doses involved. A clinical incident form should be completed as this is a potentially serious error.

Telling the nurse or doctor off is not the most pressing matter here. They are likely to be mortified by the error and a more supportive discussion by their respective senior colleagues is more appropriate. Yellow cards were not designed for this kind of scenario.

Transferring her to a liver ward is over the top and likely to alarm the patient.

options: Write a reply to the consultant saying that you were disappointed by the tone of his letter and felt discussing knee replacement was appropriate
Write a letter stating that you will not refer patients to him on a private basis unless he writes you a letter of apology

Write to the consultant stating that you were sorry to hear that he was annoyed but you felt discussing knee replacement was appropriate. Ask him to clarify the referral criteria for knee replacements
Call the patient in, explain the contents of the letter and put your point of view across
Take no action
questions:
You are a GP registrar. You receive a letter from an orthopaedic consultant after referring a 60-year-old man with right knee osteoarthritis. He is annoyed you discussed the possibility of a knee replacement with the patient saying that this is not yet indicated and adding that it 'made my discussions with the patient most difficult'. He advises 'it would be better if I stick to my job and you stick to yours'.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
It is not unreasonable to discuss potential secondary care management with a patient and in many ways is good practice. The letter from the consultant is therefore inappropriate.

He may have just been having a bad day. Option C is therefore the best response as it is constructive and maintains a professional relationship.

The next best option is to write a polite letter explaining your point of view. Accepting that the colleague is rude is a poor option as the consultant may not genuinely understand the role of General Practice.

Trying to get the patient on 'your side' interferes with patient care and is unprofessional. Effectively blackmailing the consultant is also a bad idea!

options: Notify the Consultant in Public Health
Explain to the patient that you will need to pass on this information
This disease does not need to be reported
Discuss with a senior colleague
Do nothing
Advise the patient to inform Public Health
Protect patient confidentiality
Obtain medico-legal advice before proceeding with the report
questions:
You are a junior doctor working in adult medicine. You have clerked in a patient who presents with fever and a history of recent foreign travel. Initial investigations suggest a diagnosis of malaria. What do you do?

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
There is a list of communicable diseases which should be reported that can be found on the link below. Malaria is a serious communicable infection and should therefore be reported if it is suspected/confirmed in a UK patient. If a doctor should find themselves in this situation, it is best practice to inform the patient of exactly what is going on and that you will have to report this case to the Consultant in Public Health. This is a medical doctor responsible for outbreak management including risk assessment, preventative screening, education and collation of data regarding outbreaks. Another sensible option of the remaining would be (as always) to discuss with a colleague.

Although as a general rule you should not break patient confidentiality, this is one of the few situations where it is appropriate to, as the needs of the general public outweigh the confidentiality of the patient. You as the doctor are the person responsible for informing Public Health, not the patient. Finally, it is not a requirement to obtain legal advice prior to reporting.

http://www.gmc-uk.org/guidance/ethicalguidance/28429.asp
https://www.gov.uk/guidance/notifiable-diseases-and-causative-organisms-how-to-report

title: General Medical Council: duties of a doctor
body:
Make the care of your patient your first concern

Protect and promote the health of patients and the public
  • Provide a good standard of practice and care
  • Keep your professional knowledge and skills up to date
  • Recognise and work within the limits of your competence
  • Work with colleagues in the ways that best serve patients' interests

Treat patients as individuals and respect their dignity
  • Treat patients politely and considerately
  • Respect patients' right to confidentiality

Work in partnership with patients
  • Listen to patients and respond to their concerns and preferences
  • Give patients the information they want or need in a way they can understand
  • Respect patients' right to reach decisions with you about their treatment and care
  • Support patients in caring for themselves to improve and maintain their health

Be honest and open and act with integrity
  • Act without delay if you have good reason to believe that you or a colleague may be putting patients at risk
  • Never discriminate unfairly against patients or colleagues
  • Never abuse your patients' trust in you or the public's trust in the profession.
concept: In the case of certain communicable diseases, this is a situation in which you can break confidentiality by reporting to Public Health, but it is good practice to inform the patient of what you are doing

options: Report this to your child protection officer
Give her the information regarding attending the GUM clinic and arrange an appointment for her
Do a urine dip. If it is negative, advise her to buy some clotrimazole over the counter
Refer to the gynaecology SHO on call as you are not comfortable performing an internal examination
Ensure that you take a full sexual history and explore the patients concerns around the discharge
Tell her that she ought to use barrier contraception
Do a pregnancy test
Report to the police as she is underage
questions:
You see a 15-year-old girl in the emergency department who reports some vaginal discharge and pelvic pain. She says that she has been having regular unprotected sexual intercourse with her 17-year-old boyfriend. He is present with her, appears supportive and is relating appropriately.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
This question explores your understanding around the age of consent and its application. It also explores your ability to make decisions with regards to screening and implementing treatment.

In this situation, there is age appropriate relationship, which is sexual in nature. This would not warrant involvement of the child protection officer, or the police (options 1 or 8).

You should, of course, take a full history (5), and rule out any ectopic pregnancy (7). In this situation, the patient is going to be best managed in a GUM clinic which can provide a full assessment, follow up and contraceptive advise in a way that you will not be able to in the emergency department. So the other best option is 2. Option 4 would be an inappropriate referral. Option 6, although true, is unlikely to change the patient's behaviour and won't deal with the current symptoms.
question:
You see a 15-year-old girl in the emergency department who reports some vaginal discharge and pelvic pain. She says that she has been having regular unprotected sexual intercourse with her 17-year-old boyfriend. He is present with her, appears supportive and is relating appropriately.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
question_notes:
This question explores your understanding around the age of consent and its application. It also explores your ability to make decisions with regards to screening and implementing treatment.

In this situation, there is age appropriate relationship, which is sexual in nature. This would not warrant involvement of the child protection officer, or the police (options 1 or 8).

You should, of course, take a full history (5), and rule out any ectopic pregnancy (7). In this situation, the patient is going to be best managed in a GUM clinic which can provide a full assessment, follow up and contraceptive advise in a way that you will not be able to in the emergency department. So the other best option is 2. Option 4 would be an inappropriate referral. Option 6, although true, is unlikely to change the patient's behaviour and won't deal with the current symptoms.
